title: 105_hr2222
content: The Act titled "Federal Facilities Clean Water Compliance Act of 1997" applies certain provisions to federal facilities. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include various requirements, administrative authority, and sanctions, waiving any immunity for the United States. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include requirements, administrative authority, and sanctions, waiving immunity for the United States. No agent, employee, or officer of the United States shall be personally liable for civil penalties under water pollution laws for acts within official duties. An agent, employee, or officer of the United States is not subject to criminal sanctions under water pollution laws, but government departments are exempt from such sanctions. SEC. 3. FEDERAL FACILITY ENFORCEMENT. Section 309 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include Federal Facility Enforcement, allowing the Administrator to issue compliance orders to federal departments, agencies, or instrumentalities found in violation of specific sections of the Act or permit conditions. The Administrator can issue compliance orders to federal departments, agencies, or instrumentalities for violations of specific sections of the Act or permit conditions. The Secretary of the Army can also take action if there are violations related to discharges of dredged or fill material. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates can issue orders to assess penalties or require compliance for violations of section 311 of the Act or its regulations. The order may include suspension or revocation of permits by the Administrator. The Secretary of the Army may issue orders to assess penalties or require compliance for violations of the Act, including suspension or revocation of permits. The penalty for each violation shall not exceed $25,000 per day. Any order becomes final unless a public hearing is requested within 30 days. The Administrator or Secretary can conduct a public hearing under section 554 of title 5, United States Code, issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents, and set rules for discovery procedures. If a violator does not comply with an order, a civil penalty of up to $25,000 per day may be assessed. The Administrator or Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke permits issued under sections 402 or 404 of the Act. When determining penalties, they consider the seriousness of violations, economic benefits, prior violations, and efforts to comply. The Administrator may issue emergency orders and assess penalties for violations at federal facilities, including Federal agencies. Consultation with the Administrator is required before any administrative order becomes final for Federal departments, agencies, or instrumentalities. The subsection outlines that no instrumentality shall become final until consultation with the Administrator is completed. It also states that existing compliance orders will not be affected and that civil enforcement actions can still be pursued for violations. Public notice is required before issuing an order under this subsection. Before issuing an order under this subsection, the Administrator or Secretary must provide public notice and a chance for public comment. Any person commenting on the order will be notified of any hearing and given the opportunity to present evidence. If no hearing is held, individuals who commented on the order can petition within 30 days of its issuance. Within 30 days of the order issuance, the Administrator or Secretary must set aside the order and provide a hearing if new material evidence is presented by the petitioner. The affected Federal department, agency, or instrumentality must be notified and allowed to participate in the hearing. If a hearing is denied, the Administrator must inform the petitioner and the affected Federal department. The order issued under this subsection becomes final 30 days after issuance unless withdrawn or a hearing is requested. If a hearing is denied, the order becomes final 30 days after denial. If granted, the order becomes final 30 days after the decision. Any person can initiate a civil action against a Federal agency. Any Federal agency alleged to violate an order issued by the Administrator or the Secretary under this title must pay a penalty within 1 year of the final order's effective date. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act regarding the determination of civil penalties. SEC. 5 expands the definition of "person" to include any department, agency, or instrumentality of the United States. SEC. 6 defines radioactive material. SEC. 6 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include a definition of radioactive material, encompassing source materials, special nuclear materials, and byproduct materials used outside Nuclear Regulatory Commission licensed facilities.
